_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.    Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of M & M Service Atwater are committed to the prevention
of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Carlinville Fire Department, Macoupin County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

     2. The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.

This is a normally unmanned facility. The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 22894 Main St. is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. The storage and handling system consists of a 30,000 gallon storage tanks, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks and a rail siding with capacity for holding two railcars. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 761,400 pounds; this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks and the two railcars.
   
    3. The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario

This facility has developed a worst-case and alternative-case scenario, however, since this is security-sensitive information it has been withheld from this Executive Summary as required by EPA regulations.

   4. The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by

state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.
 
  5. Five year accident history. 

 There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
- have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor
- to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

   6. The emergency response program.

The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38; provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).
In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the
Carlinville Fire Department and Macoupin County LEPC and request that they respond to
the emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire
department and LEPC.

   7. Planned changes to improve safety. 

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. We have added u-locks to the service valves of our nurse tanks. The facility is well lit at night. Safety inspections on equipment are done on a regular basis. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
